If a type is both empty and a fintype, then its cardinality is zero.

type: ‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : Fintype Œ±] [inst_1 : IsEmpty Œ±], Fintype.card Œ± = 0

docString: If a type is both empty and a fintype, then its cardinality is zero.

This theorem states that the "birthday" of the zero game in set theory is zero. The birthday of a pre-game is defined as the least strict upper bound of the birthdays of its left and right games. In the context of games, it can be viewed as the "step" in which a certain game is constructed. In the case of the zero game, since there are no preceding steps (or in other words, no left or right games), its birthday is thus defined to be zero.

type: SetTheory.PGame.birthday 0 = 0
name: SetTheory.PGame.birthday_zero
docString: This theorem states that the "birthday" of the zero game in set theory is zero. The birthday of a pre-game is defined as the least strict upper bound of the birthdays of its left and right games. In the context of games, it can be viewed as the "step" in which a certain game is constructed. In the case of the zero game, since there are no preceding steps (or in other words, no left or right games), its birthday is thus defined to be zero.

For any topological space `Œ±` and pseudo metric space `Œ≤` with defined zero, the constant function `0 : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤` equals the zero function.

This theorem states that for any topological space `Œ±` and any discrete topological space `Y`, if `Œ±` is preconnected and `f` is a continuous function from `Œ±` to `Y`, then the function `f` will produce the same output for any two inputs `x` and `y` from `Œ±`. This is a version of `isPreconnected.constant` theorem specialized for `PreconnectedSpace`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace Œ±] {Y : Type u_3} [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Y] [inst_2 : DiscreteTopology Y],
  PreconnectedSpace Œ± ‚Üí ‚àÄ {f : Œ± ‚Üí Y}, Continuous f ‚Üí ‚àÄ {x y : Œ±}, f x = f y
name: PreconnectedSpace.constant
docString: This theorem states that for any topological space `Œ±` and any discrete topological space `Y`, if `Œ±` is preconnected and `f` is a continuous function from `Œ±` to `Y`, then the function `f` will produce the same output for any two inputs `x` and `y` from `Œ±`. This is a version of `isPreconnected.constant` theorem specialized for `PreconnectedSpace`.

**Minimum principle** for concave functions on a segment. If a function `f` is concave on the
segment `[x, y]`, then the eventual minimum of `f` on `[x, y]` is at `x` or `y`.

type:
‚àÄ {ùïú : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} {Œ≤ : Type u_4} [inst : LinearOrderedField ùïú] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : LinearOrderedAddCommGroup Œ≤] [inst_3 : Module ùïú E] [inst_4 : Module ùïú Œ≤] [inst_5 : OrderedSMul ùïú Œ≤]
  {f : E ‚Üí Œ≤} {x y z : E}, ConcaveOn ùïú (segment ùïú x y) f ‚Üí z ‚àà segment ùïú x y ‚Üí min (f x) (f y) ‚â§ f z
name: ConcaveOn.min_le_of_mem_segment
docString:
**Minimum principle** for concave functions on a segment. If a function `f` is concave on the
segment `[x, y]`, then the eventual minimum of `f` on `[x, y]` is at `x` or `y`.

The highest regular priority for spawned tasks: `8`.

Spawning a task with a priority higher than `Task.Priority.max` is not an error but
will spawn a dedicated worker for the task, see `Task.Priority.dedicated`.
Regular priority tasks are placed in a thread pool and worked on according to the priority order.

type: Task.Priority
name: Task.Priority.max
docString:
The highest regular priority for spawned tasks: `8`.

Spawning a task with a priority higher than `Task.Priority.max` is not an error but
will spawn a dedicated worker for the task, see `Task.Priority.dedicated`.
Regular priority tasks are placed in a thread pool and worked on according to the priority order.

The rank of a module as a natural number.

Defined by convention to be `0` if the space has infinite rank.

For a vector space `M` over a field `R`, this is the same as the finite dimension
of `M` over `R`.

type: (R : Type u_1) ‚Üí (M : Type u_2) ‚Üí [inst : Semiring R] ‚Üí [inst_1 : AddCommGroup M] ‚Üí [inst : Module R M] ‚Üí ‚Ñï
name: FiniteDimensional.finrank
docString:
The rank of a module as a natural number.

Defined by convention to be `0` if the space has infinite rank.

For a vector space `M` over a field `R`, this is the same as the finite dimension
of `M` over `R`.
